{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient is presenting with urinary leakage that has been progressively worsening over the past year. Initially, the leakage only occurred during athletic exercise, but now it occurs with laughing or coughing as well. The patient also reports increased frequency of urination and waking up once at night to urinate. These symptoms are consistent with stress urinary incontinence, which is the most common type of urinary incontinence in women. Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by the involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, laughing, or exercising. Risk factors for stress urinary incontinence include pregnancy, vaginal delivery, and obesity. In this case, the patient had a vaginal delivery 10 years ago and a cesarean section 4 years ago, which are both risk factors for stress urinary incontinence. The patient's pelvic examination and speculum examination were unremarkable, ruling out any anatomical abnormalities. When the patient is asked to perform a Valsalva maneuver, leakage of urine is observed, further supporting the diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence. Therefore, the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is urethral hypermobility, which is the result of weakened pelvic floor muscles and connective tissue that support the urethra.", "answer_choice": "C"}
